title: ğŸ® AWS IoT Commands Manager
learning_description:
This script helps you explore AWS IoT Commands - a feature for sending real-time commands
to IoT devices. You'll learn how to create command commands, execute commands to devices,
monitor command status, and understand when to use Commands vs Device Shadow vs Jobs.
This is essential for implementing remote control capabilities in IoT applications.

what_are_commands.header: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: What are Commands?
what_are_commands.content:
Commands are reusable definitions that specify the structure
for command executions you send to devices. Think of them as blueprints that ensure consistency
and validation across all command executions.

Key benefits:
â€¢ Consistency: All commands follow the same structure
â€¢ Reusability: Create once, use many times
â€¢ Documentation: Commands serve as API documentation for devices

commands_vs_shadow_vs_jobs.header: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Commands vs Device Shadow vs Jobs
commands_vs_shadow_vs_jobs.content:
AWS IoT provides three ways to interact with devices:

ğŸ® Commands (this feature):
â€¢ Use for: Immediate, real-time actions requiring quick response
â€¢ Examples: Lock/unlock, horn activation, emergency stop
â€¢ Response time: Seconds
â€¢ Offline behavior: Fails if device offline

ğŸ”„ Device Shadow:
â€¢ Use for: Desired state synchronization
â€¢ Examples: Temperature settings, configuration
â€¢ Response time: Eventual consistency
â€¢ Offline behavior: Syncs when device reconnects

ğŸ“¦ Jobs:
â€¢ Use for: Long-running operations, batch updates
â€¢ Examples: Firmware updates, certificate rotation
â€¢ Response time: Minutes to hours
â€¢ Offline behavior: Queues and executes when available

mqtt_topics.header: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: MQTT Topic Structure
mqtt_topics.content:
Commands use reserved MQTT topics for communication:

Request topic (device subscribes):
$aws/commands/things/{thingName}/executions/+/request/json

Response topic (device publishes):
$aws/commands/things/{thingName}/executions/{executionId}/response/json

The '+' wildcard subscribes to all execution IDs.
The '#' wildcard subscribes to all payload formats.

execution_lifecycle.header: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Command Execution Lifecycle
execution_lifecycle.content:
Commands go through several states:

1. CREATED: Command created but not yet sent
2. IN_PROGRESS: Command sent to device, awaiting response
3. SUCCEEDED: Device acknowledged successful execution
4. FAILED: Device reported execution failure
5. TIMED_OUT: No response received within timeout
6. CANCELED: Command canceled by user

Monitoring these states helps you understand device behavior and troubleshoot issues.

best_practices.content:
Follow these best practices for production deployments:

â€¢ Test commands on a single device before fleet-wide deployment
â€¢ Set appropriate timeouts based on expected execution time
â€¢ Implement proper error handling on devices
â€¢ Log all command executions for audit trails
â€¢ Use thing groups for targeting multiple devices
â€¢ Monitor command success rates and investigate failures
â€¢ Cancel commands that are taking too long

console_integration.content:
Don't forget to complete the Console Checkpoint in the workshop!

In the AWS IoT Console, you can:
â€¢ View all commands
â€¢ See command execution timeline
â€¢ Monitor command status visually
â€¢ Compare CLI operations with Console UI

This helps you understand the relationship between CLI and Console interfaces.

integration.terminal_setup_reminder: âš ï¸  CRITICAL: Terminal Setup Order
integration.terminal_setup_warning: You MUST set up the device simulator (Terminal 2) BEFORE executing commands!
integration.terminal_setup_reason:
Commands are ephemeral - if no device is listening when the command is published,
it will be lost. Always ensure your device simulator is running and subscribed
to command topics before executing commands from Terminal 1.
